text: we're joined now by Democratic Senator
Michael Bennet of Colorado who was
appointed to the job in 2009 now is
running for election to a full term
thanks for being with us thanks for
having me we're Barack Obama's economic
policies the wrong ones or were they the
right ones and they just haven't had
enough time to work I think history is
going to judge that what I would say is
that last March or februari right after
I was put in this job when I was
visiting with friends of mine from the
business community and Colorado in other
places if I'd said to them you know and
September eight their September ninth of
next year what you're going to see is
three quarters of gdp growth the stock
market back to roughly where it is today
seventy-five percent of the tarp money
paid back with a profit to the taxpayers
and GM about ready to go public last
spring we would have settled for that
now have the economic policies been
perfect or not we'll have to wait and
see the problem right now is we have
very slow growth and very high
unemployment what should we do about
those two problems growth and jobs right
now I think what we need to recognize
first is how we got into this mess to
begin with because we are going through
and my family's in Colorado are going
through the most savage economy that
we've seen since the Great Depression
but even before we were in this economic
downturn if you look at the last period
of economic growth in our country's
history it's the first time ever in the
entire history of the country that our
economy grew and median family income
fell that had never happened before so
our families earning a thousand dollars
less at the end of the decade in
Colorado than they were at the beginning
in real dollars while their costs of
health insurance has gone up by 97%
their cost of higher ed by over fifty
percent we've created no net new jobs in
the United States since 1998 and a
household wealth is the same at the end
of the decade as it was the beginning
that's never happened before since we
started measuring this right after World
War Two and we've got 13 trillion
dollars of debt on the down on the
balance sheet and failed to invest in
our roads or bridges or toes or
wastewater systems so forth so we are
starting this new century way behind
I believe the first decade of this new
century was basically a complete waste
of time false economy and what we need
are set of tax policies and regulatory
policies inspire innovation in this
country and make us the most competitive
economy of the world and as long as
these politicians in Washington want to
keep fighting over stuff that has
nothing to do the facts we're not going
to get to where we need so the president
this week said what we need to do our to
make the R&D tax credit permanent we
need to allow businesses to immediately
write off new investments and we need to
spend 50 billion dollars on new
infrastructure as he got it right I
think he's got a right until the 50
billion dollars in new infrastructure
and look I'd love to be investing our
infrastructure just like everybody else
would like to be but from the point of
view people in Colorado I think the way
we see it is if we're going to be
spending money on infrastructure we
ought to use the money that was in the
first stimulus that hasn't yet been
spent I think there's more we can do to
accelerate the economy and make sure the
credit is flowing to small businesses we
ought to think differently about how
we're amortizes that community and
regional banks are suffering as a result
of the melton or a commercial real
estate market and we need our regulators
to acknowledge the fact that we're going
through a once-in-a-lifetime economic
downturn and for them to be pushing so
hard on the balance sheets of our
community and regional banks so that
they can't lend money to small business
is completely self-defeating was the
first stimulus package that you voted
for too small or too big I think we're
not going to again I think it's one of
those things it's too early to write the
history of it and we're just going to
have to see it my sense of it is that
economists both Democrats and
Republicans many of them agree that it's
responsible for roughly three percent of
GDP growth who knows whether the right
or the wrong were you know in a an
economy that I think has severe
structural issues because of all the
reasons I talked about it earlier and
it's not a situation it's going to be
solved by sound bites or by kind of the
foolish politics of Washington DC Peter
Orszag the president's former budget
director wrote an op at the other
where he said that we should extend the
tax cuts for the middle class for two
years and if it's necessary to get a
deal extend them for the rich for two
years because the economy doesn't
shouldn't take tax increases right now
but they ought to expire after that and
they ought to go away because we need
more revenue to bring the deficit down
is that right well I read his piece and
the way I interpreted what he was saying
was that he thought that it was
important for a compromise to get a deal
done to maybe delay all of the
expiration of the text but the punch
line was he wants them all to go away in
a few years yeah well here's the punch
line the punch line is that if you look
at our revenue line and you look at what
it covers what it covers is Medicare
medics acuity and interest on our debt
which means that virtually everything
else we spend money on whether it's
schools teachers bombers that we build
anything that anybody at the Interior
Department or any of these other
departments are doing we're borrowing
from our children and I think what we
have to do and this is hard for
Washington to do is look at this
comprehensively and say how is it that
we're going to establish some fiscal
sanity going forward because the capital
markets I'm going to put up with this
much longer and if they don't our
interest rates are rates are going to
spike and and this recession is going to
seem modest compared to what's going to
happen it so it sounds like you think
Orszag is right and that the tax cuts
because we need revenue to make the
books balanced the tax cuts ought to go
away in a couple of years I think some
of the tax cuts ought to go away but I
don't think the question is the right
question because we look at these things
in isolation right instead of
understanding the burden and it is a
burden of taxes as a comprehensive
question that asks the question are we
rewarding folks for innovating in the
United States are we rewarding them for
creating jobs through our tax policy
because if people are hiring people and
they're paying people they're paying
more taxes in to look at the bush tax
cuts it's a perfect Washington case in
isolation from corporate taxes in
isolation from what we're doing with
small business makes no sense to me and
maybe this is because I've spent my
entire life outside
politics maybe that's because I spent
half my life turning around distress
companies but it just does not make
sense to me to look at your revenues in
this siloed way and also not to consider
your expenses as well well talking about
systemic reform your opponent ken buck
says we might be better off to shift
away from income taxes toward
consumption taxes or sales taxes you see
on to something some economist think
that would be good for the economy yeah
I i think his proposals here are just
not what we need it's not what Colorado
wants the idea that you had cut taxes on
the wealthiest two percent of Americans
but effectively give the average
Colorado and a thirty percent tax
increase makes no sense to me uh where
did he propose that that's that's the
bets the math on the flat tax that he's
proposed the buck also said that he is
open to indexing the retirement age for
Social Security do you what would you be
willing as a Democrat who's serious
about Budget Responsibility what would
you be willing to put on the table on
social I actually think Social Security
is the easiest of all these issues to
solve and and there are ways of changing
the retirement age for people much
younger than I am today I'm 45 that
would make the program sustainable into
the future I don't think we should
change it for people that have retired
or anywhere near retirement but I think
we ought to have a conversation about
how we're going to do this going forward
so not a bad idea to entertain that for
younger workers yeah but you don't
terminate Jim much I what about the idea
of Medicare you've already put a bunch
of savings on the table in health care
reform in Medicare what else are you
willing to do on that regard it was my
biggest disappointment with the health
care discussion was that we didn't do as
much as we should have done on cost
almost all of my amendments were related
to cause and the the changes to Medicare
that it that some of us were trying to
make was moving us from a
fee-for-service system closer to a
reimbursement system based on outcomes
based on performance which makes all the
sense in the
all the interested in driving quality
and if you're interested in saving money
so we need to go back to that there's so
much more we need to do i'll give you an
example the hospital readmission rate in
this country right now is twenty percent
one out of every five Medicare patients
this release from the hospital is
readmitted within the first month that
they're released there are hospitals all
over this country from the Mayo Clinic
to st. Mary's Hospital in Grand Junction
Colorado that have a hospital
readmission rate of less than three
percent because they have a system of
electronic medical records and because
they've got a system in place that
follows the patient from their emergency
bed to the emergency room to their
hospital bed to their primary care
physician to their mental health
provider today Medicare doesn't remember
it actually does now because of an
amendment that I wrote on the health
care bill but before that Medicare
doesn't reimburse anybody for that and
what my amendment said was simply you
know if you've got a system in place
that's saving money and driving quality
you should be reimbursed for that rather
than the old system which said we're
reimbursing you for the first visit
we're reimbursing you for the second
visit without regard to what you're
doing in between that makes no sense a
lot of conservatives say a part of the
answer for Medicare is to convert to the
use of vouchers is that an answer I
don't think I don't think it's a
realistic answer I think that what we
can do is figure out how to change this
incentive structure to save costs look
you know this was all described as a
Bolshevik take over the United States or
government take over the United States
the reality is that before this health
care bill passed which by the way I'm
the first to say it is far from perfect
every single day in this country
thousands of people were being thrown
off their private insurance and small if
you look at the small businesses that
were ensuring people it looks you know
drops like a stone because it's
completely unaffordable to small
business and to individuals and they
were ending up in one of two places if
they were poor enough they were ending
up on Medicaid a public plan if they
weren't poor enough there anything up in
the emergency room getting uncommon
sated care that we the taxpayer we the
policyholder are paying for that is a
government takeover of health care it's
just the most expensive and least
intentional
the way you could possibly design it and
I think we now have an architecture in
place that needs to be refined and needs
to be improved and we need to continue
to drive the cost curve down or we're
going to bankrupt not just our small
businesses and not just our families but
the country as well a couple things for
I let you go it appears that you have
not taken a stand on the employee Free
Choice Act why not actually that's not
right and but I'm happy to take sure to
take it now this is a bill that clearly
is not going to come to the floor of the
Senate it's not going to pass the Senate
it is a bill that is dividing people at
a time in our economy when we need labor
and management working together to
rebuild this economy and so I don't see
a lot of point in dwelling on it what I
you know and I've spent a lot of time
and collective bargaining relationships
one way or another I believe in
collective bargaining and believe in the
right of workers to organize but even
more than that I really believe in a
politics where our business community
and our labor community are not
demonizing each other we need a politics
that's actually going to lift the middle
class up in this country and that's what
I'm focused on well so does that mean
that you're against it that you don't
think it's appropriate to be brought up
now because the votes aren't there I
think it will not be brought up it has
not been brought up and I've been
spending my time paying attention to our
economy right be you so you haven't said
how you would vote on the bill if it
were brought I haven't I've said you
know I have issues with the way the bill
is written otherwise I would have been a
co-sponsor of the bill and I'm not a
co-sponsor of the bill but I think that
it is an a classic Washington issue
that's man that's mentioned it's meant
to distract people from what we're
really trying to work on by the way on
both sides I mean we need our folks
pulling together here in this economic
catastrophe on your side a lot of
Democrats have thought that after the
health care bill was passed and the
administration had a chance to explain
it it would grow in popularity with the
American people polls don't seem to bear
that out why do you think it hasn't
happened I think you know and this is
the perspective of somebody who bears
some very serious car
from being involved in school reform
efforts at the local level no matter how
much you think the system isn't working
and no matter how much everyone else
thinks it might not be working people
have a tendency to believe deeply in the
capacity of people like me I don't mean
me personally but folks that are doing
this work to make the situation even
worse and I saw that in school reform
and I saw that in the health care bill
people said you know a michael i hate
the system as it is right now but i
think you guys are going to make it even
worse we need a better more elevated
standard than that i think for us to be
able to achieve on behalf of our working
families and our kids and our grandkids
I think we've done a lousy job
explaining what's in the bill where did
that depth of cynicism come from which
the one that you just mentioned where
where no matter how broken people think
the system is they cost people like you
and say in mind a message in my in my
town hall meetings and read parts the
state in blue parts estate and the ones
i love the best are the ones where
they're democrats republicans tea party
folks all kinds of people so folks have
to listen to each other which is one of
the problems that ALS we're not
listening to each other enough in their
daily lives people are going through the
worst economy since the Great Depression
and as a generation the anxiety is that
we could be the first generation of
Americans to leave less opportunity not
more to our kids and our grandkids every
other generation of Americans has
figured out how to sort that out when
people see the screaming on the cable TV
when they see the debate on the Senate
floor that bears no relationship to the
issues that they're actually confronting
that's what breeds it and I wouldn't
describe it as cynicism I just say it
breeds skepticism that people in
Washington are talking about anything
other than their own incumbency or
what's wrong with the other person and
what they want to see are these issues
addressed in the thoughtful way and in a
way that seems relevant to their lives
that being the case you said at one
point during the health care debate you

you think that's what is going to happen
in november i think i'm going to win

thanks so much for being with thanks for
